description:
Ban Mido and Ginji Amano run a freelance business of recovering anything lost or stolen from a client—and they claim a 100% success rate. They call themselves the GetBackers, and they're a super powered duo whose job lands them in dangerous predicaments. Although they have many adventures on their recovery quests, each has a mysterious past that rears its ugly head at the most inoportune moments. It's wild and crazy and one awesome anime ride!

(Source: Sentai Filmworks)

tags.name: Super Power
tags.description: Prominently features characters with special abilities that allow them to do what would normally be physically or logically impossible.

tags.name: Crime
tags.description: Centers around unlawful activities punishable by the state or other authority.

tags.name: Urban
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a city.

tags.name: Work
tags.description: Centers around the activities of a certain occupation.

tags.name: Urban Fantasy
tags.description: Set in a world similar to the real world, but with the existence of magic or other supernatural elements.

tags.name: Drugs
tags.description: Prominently features the usage of drugs such as opioids, stimulants, hallucinogens etc.

tags.name: Shounen
tags.description: Target demographic is teenage and young adult males.

tags.name: Martial Arts
tags.description: Centers around the use of traditional hand-to-hand combat.

tags.name: Ensemble Cast
tags.description: Features a large cast of characters with (almost) equal screen time and importance to the plot.

tags.name: Virtual World
tags.description: Partly or completely set in the world inside a video game.

tags.name: Yakuza
tags.description: Centered around Japanese organised crime syndicates.

tags.name: Mafia
tags.description: Centered around Italian organised crime syndicates.

tags.name: Chibi
tags.description: Features "super deformed" character designs with smaller, rounder proportions and a cute look.

title.native: ゲットバッカーズ -奪還屋-

node.description:
__Education__:
- 1987: Waseda University School of Economics & Political Science
- Tokyo Metropolitan Musashi Senior High School

__Pennames__: 
- [Agi Tadashi](https://anilist.co/staff/105010/Tadashi-Agi), shared with his older sister, Yuko Kibayashi (樹林ゆう子), non-fiction writer.
- Seimaru Amagi (_天樹征丸_)
- Yuma Ando (_安童夕馬_)
- Yuya Aoki (_青樹佑夜_)
- Joji Arimori (_有森丈時_)
- Hiroaki Igano (_伊賀大晃_)
- Ryo Ryumon (_龍門諒_)
- S.K.

Received the Kodansha Manga Award for Shounen in 1995 (The Kindaichi Case Files) and in 2003 (Kunimitsu no Matsuri).

[Blog](https://sijimi217.hatenadiary.org/) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/rand_usatan)

A Japanese manga artist, known for creating the manga series GetBackers and Majestic Prince. After graduating from the Tokyo Animator Academy, he worked for some time as [Tooru Fujisawa](https://anilist.co/staff/97318/Tooru-Fujisawa)'s assistant.

**[Profile (Office Without)](http://www.officewithout.com/iwasaki.html)** | **[Twitter](https://twitter.com/taque68)** | **[MySpace](https://myspace.com/taqueiwasaki)** | **[Blog (JP)](https://ameblo.jp/soundtrack-maker)**

A composer and musician generally known for his jazz-like scores.

When he was 3 years old he was given a piano, he was also taken to Yamaha Music School, where he first came into contact with music. He quit music school as an elementary school student and, until his high school years, studied under Iwashita Tetsuya, who taught him how to use multiple recordings and synthesizers. He became a composer in his later high school years, through the various efforts made by himself and his teacher.

In 1985, he won a prize at the Kanagawa Arts Festival choral composition competition, while in the late 1980s, after entering Tokyo University of the Arts, he studied contemporary music under Satou Shin and Aoshima Hiroshi. While still being a student, he received the New Artist Award from the Japan Contemporary Music Association. He later started working as an arranger after graduating from college.

In 1999, he participated in the music unit "Smart Drug" with Koizumi Hiroshi, who was responsible for doing the composition and playing the guitar, and Okamoto Sayori who would later rename to Hiyoko, who was responsible for doing the lyrics and vocals. He participated under the alias "Taque," where he was responsible for the arrangement and playing the keyboard. They released three CDs from 1999 to 2002.

(Source: Wikipedia)
[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/古橋一浩)
[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/古橋一浩)

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/_7265687568142)

Freelancer with a desk at [Studio Deen](https://anilist.co/studio/37/). Nakajima is strongly associated with the animated adaptations of the works of [Rumiko Takahashi](https://anilist.co/staff/96891/), having worked as an animation director on [Urusei Yatsura](https://anilist.co/anime/1293/), [Maison Ikkoku](https://anilist.co/anime/1453/) and [Ranma ½](https://anilist.co/anime/210/) also also serving as the character designer on latter.

She is married to [Tomohiro Hirata](https://anilist.co/staff/122071/).

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/鶴岡陽太)

Founder and representative director of [Rakuonsha](https://anilist.co/studio/211/).

Bon-Bon Blanco (sometimes B3 or B3) was a Japanese rock group active during 2002~2009.

__Members:__
• Anna Santos (サントス・アンナ Santosu Anna, born July 9, 1987) – Main Vocals
• Izumi (中台泉美 Nakadai Izumi, born January 2, 1988) – Conga (left in 2008)
• Mako (桜井真子 Sakurai Mako, born October 7, 1986) – Maracas
• Ruri (水谷光里 Mizutani Ruri, born January 7, 1990) – Bongo
• Tomoyo (松本知世 Matsumoto Tomoyo, born March 2, 1987) – Timbales
[Twitter](https://twitter.com/azukosotokam)
[Twitter](https://twitter.com/omodeakemi)
[Website](https://pastel-works0.webnode.jp) | [Blog](https://ameblo.jp/bigbert/) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/muratatoshiharu)
[Twitter](https://twitter.com/omodeakemi)

__Birthplace:__ Yokohama, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan
__Daughter:__ [Ryouko Maekawa](https://anilist.co/staff/120430)

__Atsushi Maekawa__ is a Japanese script/screenwriter for anime, while he also occasionally writes lyrics for music.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/吉田玲子) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reiko_Yoshida)

Yoshida has written and supervised numerous scripts for anime series, live-action dramas and films. Her major works include [Kaleido Star](https://anilist.co/anime/427), [Aria](https://anilist.co/anime/477), [Maria-sama ga Miteru](https://anilist.co/anime/158), [D.Gray-man](https://anilist.co/anime/1482), [K-On!](https://anilist.co/anime/5680), [Bakuman](https://anilist.co/anime/7674) and [Girls und Panzer](https://anilist.co/anime/14131). In more recent works, she has supervised the screenplays for [Majestic Prince](https://anilist.co/anime/15863), [Non Non Biyori](https://anilist.co/anime/17549), [A Town Where You Live](https://anilist.co/anime/17741), [Tamako Market](https://anilist.co/anime/16417), [Yowamushi Pedal](https://anilist.co/anime/18179) and [Castle Town Dandelion](https://anilist.co/anime/20951). In films, she wrote the screenplay for Ghibli's [The Cat Returns](https://anilist.co/anime/597), the original films that would make up [Digimon: The Movie](https://anilist.co/anime/2961), Kyoto Animation’s hit anime film [A Silent Voice](https://anilist.co/anime/20954), and the film adaptations of Osamu Tezuka's [Buddha](https://anilist.co/anime/7014), the last one's [second film](https://anilist.co/anime/20500) was given a stamp of approval by the Dalai Lama.

Among her works, she was recognized for Best Screenplay/Original Work for [Girls und Panzer](https://anilist.co/anime/14131) at the Tokyo Anime Award Festival in 2014, and she won another Best Screenplay/Original Work award in 2017. In 2018, she wrote the screenplay for [Violet Evergarden](https://anilist.co/anime/21827) which aired on TV in Japan and is licensed by Netflix.

Yoshida also wrote the story for the manga series [Tokyo Mew Mew](https://anilist.co/manga/30554).

(Source: Wikipedia)

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/koala_4034) | [Blog](http://koalaya.hatenablog.com)

Started off as a painter at Kozue Anime in the early '80s.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/_7265687568142)

Freelancer with a desk at [Studio Deen](https://anilist.co/studio/37/). Nakajima is strongly associated with the animated adaptations of the works of [Rumiko Takahashi](https://anilist.co/staff/96891/), having worked as an animation director on [Urusei Yatsura](https://anilist.co/anime/1293/), [Maison Ikkoku](https://anilist.co/anime/1453/) and [Ranma ½](https://anilist.co/anime/210/) also also serving as the character designer on latter.

She is married to [Tomohiro Hirata](https://anilist.co/staff/122071/).
A regular presence in [David Production](https://anilist.co/studio/287/)'s shows.

Known for challenging camera angles and his ultramodern usage of CG backgrounds. Him and [Hirofumi Suzuki](https://anilist.co/staff/101188/) are known as the "Golden Combo" together and their most notable works are [Neoranga](https://anilist.co/anime/1163/) and [Kaze no Youjinbou](https://anilist.co/anime/1145/). The duo were also often seen working on episodes in the [Naruto](https://anilist.co/anime/20/) series.

His pen-name Yasuaki Kurozu (黒津安明), comes from the names of [Akira Kurosawa (黒澤明)](https://anilist.co/staff/100099/) and Yasujirou Ozu (小津安二郎), two prominent Japanese film directors.
Kouichi Oohata is a director and mecha designer best known for creating the Gunbuster from *Top wo Nerae!*

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/kamitsubonpu)

Adept in composite work.
